questions.text: A 28 y/o female presents with a history of chronic constipation, rectal pain, and bleeding. On examination, an ulcer is found on the anterior wall of the rectum, 7 cm from the anal verge. Proctography reveals rectal intussusception. Which is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) STARR Procedure

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms and examination & diagnostic findings, lead us to the diagnosis of solitary rectal ulcer syndrome (SRUS)
  • The STARR procedure (Stapled Transanal Resection of the Rectum) is the preferred surgical treatment for rectal intussusception associated with SRUS, addressing both the underlying intussusception and the ulcer.


Solitary Rectal Ulcer Syndrome (SRUS)

  • SRUS can be associated with obstructed defecation syndrome.
  • Location: Typically presents as an ulcer on the anterior wall of the rectum, 6–8 cm from the anal verge.
  • The ulcer may heal and leave a polypoid appearance.
  • Diagnostic Tools:
    • Proctography: May reveal rectal intussusception or anterior rectal wall prolapse.
    • Histology: Confirms the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical Options:
      • STARR Procedure: Stapled Transanal Resection of the Rectum.
      • Abdominal Rectopexy: Resuspension of the rectum.
         

Abdominal Rectopexy (Option B) is another surgical option for rectal prolapse but is generally more invasive and typically reserved for cases of full-thickness rectal prolapse, not the localized intussusception seen in SRUS.

Histology (Option C) is crucial for confirming the diagnosis of SRUS, but it is a diagnostic tool, not a treatment modality.

Colostomy (Option D) is not indicated in the management of SRUS; it is typically reserved for more severe anorectal malformations or cases where bowel rest is required.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male presents with rectal bleeding and pain during defecation. O/E, a firm mass is palpable in the anal canal. A biopsy confirms carcinoma of the anal canal. Imaging shows no distant metastasis, but inguinal nodes are enlarged. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chemoradiation

Explanation:

  • The preferred treatment for carcinoma of the anal canal, particularly in the absence of distant metastasis and with localized inguinal lymph node involvement, is chemoradiation (Nigro regimen).

Treatment of Carcinoma of the Anal Canal

  1. Chemoradiation (Nigro regimen): The preferred treatment modality for carcinoma of the anal canal.
    • Chemotherapy Drugs: Commonly used drugs include 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), bleomycin, vincristine, and adriamycin.
    • Radiotherapy: Often used alone in advanced cases where the tumour is not resectable.
  2. Surgical Interventions:
    • Abdominoperineal Resection (APR) with Colostomy: Indicated for persistent or recurrent disease after combined modality therapy (CMT), or for cases where the tumor does not respond to chemoradiation.
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy: Involves using 5-FU, cisplatin, and mitomycin C before surgery to shrink the tumour.

questions.text: A 60 y/o patient is diagnosed with anal canal cancer. A tumour of size 3cm invades through the muscularis propria into the perirectal tissue, involving 4-6 regional lymph nodes without distant metastasis. Which of the following stages correctly describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage III (T1-T4, N2, M0)

Explanation:

  • The scenario indicates a tumour that invades the muscularis propria (T3) with the involvement of 4-6 regional lymph nodes (N2) and no distant metastasis (M0).

TNM Classification

Classification

Description

T0

No evidence of a primary tumour

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (localized)

Aka Bowens disease

Anal intraepithelial neoplasia(AIN) type I - III

T1

Tumor ≤ 2cm,

Invades the submucosa

T2

Tumor >2 cm but <5 cm,

Invades the muscularis propria

T3

Tumor>5 cm,

Invades the subserosa

T4

Tumour of any size that invades adjacent organs or structures eg. Vagina, urethra, Bladder

 

N0

No regional lymph node involvement

N1

Involvement of 1-3 regional lymph nodes

N2

Involvement of 4-6 regional lymph nodes

N3

Involvement of 7 or more regional lymph nodes

 

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

Staging Summary:

 

Stage

Criteria

Stage 0

Tis, N0, M0 (carcinoma in situ)

Stage I

T1-T2, N0, M0 (localized)

Stage II

T1-T2, N1, M0 (locally advanced)

Stage III

T1-T4, N2-N3, M0 (late locally advanced)

Stage IV

T1-T4, N1-N3, M1 (metastatic)

questions.text: A 58 y/o woman presents with anal pain, bleeding during bowel movements, and the presence of a palpable mass. She has a history of multiple sexual partners and was recently diagnosed with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Which of the following risk factors is most strongly associated with the development of anal canal cancer in this patient?

choices.text: HPV infection leads to anal condylomata.
Immunosuppression due to a recent organ transplant.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) HPV infection leading to anal condylomata.

Explanation:

  • The presence of extensive anal warts (condylomata) is strongly associated with HPV infection and significantly increases the risk of anal canal cancer due to the high likelihood of HPV-related changes in the anal epithelium.

Risk Factors:

 

Factor

Description

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection

Strongly linked to anal canal cancer, particularly high-risk subtypes (16, 18, 31, 33)

Anal Intraepithelial Neoplasia (AIN)

A precancerous condition significantly increases the risk of progression to anal canal cancer, especially from AIN II or III.

Immunosuppression

Individuals with weakened immune systems (e.g., HIV-positive, transplant recipients) have a higher risk due to impaired HPV response and AIN development.

Sexual Practices

Anal intercourse increases HPV transmission risk.

History of Other Genital Neoplasia

A history of vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) raises the risk.

Extensive Anogenital Condylomata

The presence of extensive anal warts linked to HPV infection elevates the risk of anal canal cancer.

questions.text: .A 78-year-old woman with a history of chronic constipation and faecal incontinence presents with a complaint of a mass that protrudes circumferentially from her anus, which she can manually reduce. She also reports occasional bleeding and difficulty with bowel movements. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perineal rectopexy

 

Explanation:

  • Perineal rectopexy is the preferred option for elderly patients or those with high surgical risk due to its lower operative morbidity and mortality, making it suitable for this 78-year-old patient.

 

Management of Rectal prolapse:

Non-Operative Management

  • Medical Treatment: Palliates symptoms of constipation and faecal incontinence with fluid intake, fibre supplements, stool softeners, and topical treatments for mucosal oedema.
  • Enemas and Suppositories: Assist in defecation and reduce symptoms.

Operative Management

  • Rectopexy is fixing the rectum to the sacrum by sutures or mesh after complete mobilization of the rectum


 

Aspect

Abdominal Rectopexy

Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

questions.text: A 58 y/o man presents with bright red blood in his stool, tenesmus, and intermittent abdominal pain for one month. A digital rectal exam reveals a hard mass 5 cm from the anal verge. Rigid sigmoidoscopy confirms a neoplasm. What is the next step to evaluate the extent of his disease?

choices.text: Perform a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.
Obtain a biopsy of the rectal mass.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Perform a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.

Explanation:

  • The patient’s clinical examination & investigation findings point toward the diagnosis of rectal cancer.
  • Performing a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is the correct next step to assess the extent of the disease and check for any distant metastases, which is essential for staging rectal carcinoma.

Investigations and Diagnosis of Rectal Carcinoma

  • Digital Rectal Examination:
    • Used to assess the size, consistency (hard), shape (Irregular), and mobility (mobile, tethered, or fixed).
    • A vaginal examination is recommended for women to check for involvement of the posterior vaginal wall.
  • Rigid Sigmoidoscopy:
    • Outpatient procedure for visualizing the neoplasm and obtaining biopsies
  • Biopsy and Histological Analysis:
    • Crucial for confirming the diagnosis and distinguishing rectal carcinoma from conditions that may mimic it, such as inflammatory strictures, granulomas, and benign adenomas.
  • Staging Investigations:
    • CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis.
    • Local pelvic imaging with MRI and/or endoluminal ultrasonography provides detailed information about local tumour spread, including infiltration into surrounding tissues and lymph node involvement.
  • Colonoscopy:
    • Essential for most patients to rule out synchronous tumours elsewhere in the colon.
    • Techniques like "dye spray" colonoscopy help differentiate benign from malignant lesions based on mucosal 'pit patterns'.
    • Proximal adenomas can be removed during the procedure; finding synchronous carcinomas may alter surgical strategy.
  • CT Colonography or Barium Enema:
    • Alternatives to colonoscopy if full visualization of the colon is not possible due to stenosing cancer.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiencing severe pain during bowel movements, bright red blood on toilet paper, and chronic anal fissures has not improved with conservative treatment and is being referred for surgery. Which surgical procedure is aimed at reducing anal sphincter tone to promote healing of the fissure while maintaining continence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lateral Internal Sphincterotomy

Explanation:

  • Lateral Internal Sphincterotomy involves dividing a portion of the internal anal sphincter, which reduces sphincter tone and allows the fissure to heal.
  • It is designed to maintain continence while addressing the fissure.
  • Management of anal fissures involves a combination of conservative and surgical interventions if conservative measures are ineffective.

Conservative Management

 

Lifestyle and Dietary Modifications

Aim: To soften stools and reduce pain

  • Increase fiber intake
  • Adequate fluid intake
  • Warm Sitz baths to relax the anal sphincter.
  • Topical anaesthetics.
  • Anorectal biofeedback: Helps patients learn to relax the anal sphincter and improve bowel control.

Pharmacological Treatment

1. Topical medications:

  • Glyceryl trinitrate (GTN) ointment (0.2%): Applied 2-3 times daily; a nitric oxide donor that promotes relaxation but may cause headaches.
  • Diltiazem (2%): Applied twice daily; a calcium channel blocker that induces sphincter relaxation with fewer side effects compared to GTN.

2. Botulinum toxin injections: 10-100 units injected into the internal anal sphincter to reduce pressure and allow healing by blocking acetylcholine release.

Surgical Interventions

Consider if conservative measures fail, especially for chronic cases.

 

Lateral Internal Sphincterotomy

Divides a small portion of the internal anal sphincter.

Approaches:

  • Closed Method: Small incision over the intersphincteric groove to divide the sphincter under the mucosa.
  • Open Technique: Incision through the anoderm for direct access to the internal sphincter.

Fissurectomy (Option A ruled out)
  • Excision of the fissure, including fibrotic edges and associated skin tags.
  • Often combined with an anal advancement flap.

Anal Advancement Flap

(Option C ruled out)
  • Used when there’s an increased risk of incontinence after sphincterotomy, especially in women post-childbirth.
  • Involves advancing a flap of healthy skin from the perianal area to cover the fissure, promoting healing and reducing tension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a recurrent anal abscess has developed an anal fistula. She is concerned about continence after surgery. Which surgical option is best to treat her condition while minimizing incontinence risk?

choices.text: Ligation of the Intersphincteric Fistula Tract (LIFT)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Ligation of the Intersphincteric Fistula Tract (LIFT)

Explanation:

  • The LIFT (Ligation of the Intersphincteric Fistula Tract) procedure is a sphincter-preserving technique that disconnects the internal opening of the fistula from the tract while minimizing damage to the anal sphincter.
  • This approach is particularly suitable for patients who are concerned about maintaining continence post-surgery, making it the most appropriate option for the patient in this scenario.

Fistula-in-Ano:

  • A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Common Treatment Options

 

Treatment

Description

Indications

Fistulotomy

(Option A ruled out)

Opening the fistula tract to heal by secondary intention.

Used for intersphincteric and trans-sphincteric fistula involving <30% of external sphincter; not for anterior fistula in women.

Fistulectomy

(Option B ruled out)

Removal of the fistula using diathermy cautery for better visualization of anatomy.

Effective for understanding the fistula's anatomy and extensions.

Setons

(Option C ruled out)

Materials are inserted into the fistula tract for drainage or gradual cutting.

Loose setons promote drainage; tight/cutting setons cut through muscle over time.

Advancement Flaps

Closing the internal opening with a flap of anorectal mucosa is used when the sphincter complex is not extensively indurated.

Effective for certain fistula configurations.

questions.text: A 1-week-old girl with a newly diagnosed rectovestibular fistula is undergoing evaluation. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for a newborn with a rectovestibular fistula?

choices.text: Initial colostomy followed by definitive pull-through operation
Wangenstein's Invertogram to determine the level of the rectal pouch
Aspiration of meconium and dye injection for fistula assessment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Initial colostomy followed by definitive pull-through operation.

Explanation:
A rectovestibular fistula is a type of high fistula in girls, which typically requires an initial colostomy to manage the bowel function. A definitive pull-through operation (posterior sagittal anorectoplasty) is then performed as a second stage to correct the malformation.

Anorectal Malformations (ARM):

 

Cause

Results from the imperfect fusion of the post-allantoic gut with the proctodaeum.

Incidence

Occurs in 1 in 4500 newborns; associated with anomalies like VATER/VACTERL, including cardiac, trachea-esophageal fistula, renal, and spinal anomalies.

Types
  • Male: Rectobulbar fistula (the fistula originating distal to the puborectalis)
  • Female: Rectovestibular fistula.

Investigations
  • Wangenstein's invertogram is used to determine the level of the rectal pouch relative to the pubococcygeal (Stephen’s) line.
  • Murugassu's technique: Involves aspiration of meconium from the rectum and dye injection to assess fistula level.
  • USG abdomen, cardiac function evaluation, MRI spine.

Treatment
  • Low Fistula: Single-stage reconstruction like anoplasty, ano vestibuloplasty, anal dilation, or incision of the anal membrane with excellent outcomes.
  • High Fistula: Initial colostomy followed by a definitive “Pull-through operation” (posterior sagittal anorectoplasty) and later colostomy closure.

Complications
  • Infection
  • Fecal fistula
  • Stenosis
  • Colitis
  • Malnutrition
  • Fecal incontinence

 

Single-stage anoplasty (Option A) is generally suitable for low fistulas, not high fistulas like the rectovestibular type.

Wangenstein's Invertogram to determine the level of the rectal pouch (Option C) is useful as a diagnostic tool rather than a treatment method.

Aspiration of meconium and dye injection for fistula assessment (Option D), Murugassu’s technique is used for assessing the level of the fistula, but it is not a treatment method.

questions.text: A 62 y/o woman diagnosed with rectal carcinoma is being evaluated for treatment options. Which of the following statements regarding the treatment strategies for rectal carcinoma is true?

choices.text: Total mesorectal excision (TME) is a method of palliative care in patients with advanced rectal cancer.
Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is used after surgical resection to minimize the risk of local recurrence.
Local excision is indicated for early-stage rectal cancers with good prognostic factors.
Abdominoperineal excision (APR) is the preferred surgical approach for all cases of rectal carcinoma.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Local excision is indicated for early-stage rectal cancers with good prognostic factors.

Explanations:

  • Local excision is appropriate for early-stage cancers(T1 & T2), allowing for the removal of the tumour while preserving the rectum and anal sphincter, thus minimizing the impact on bowel function.

Treatment Options for Rectal Carcinoma

Surgical Treatment

  • Goals of Surgery: Achieve complete oncological clearance by removing the tumour, surrounding mesorectum, and lymph nodes (Total Mesorectal Excision - TME) to minimize local recurrence risk.
  • TME is a curative and gold-standard approach to completely removing rectal cancer. (Option A ruled out)
  • Neoadjuvant Therapy:
    • Chemoradiotherapy is often used before surgery to downstage cancer, facilitating easier removal and improving resection success. (Option B ruled out)

Surgical Techniques:

Technique

Indications

Local Excision

(Option C)

Suitable for early-stage cancers (T1 and selected T2) with good prognostic factors; preserves rectum and anal sphincter, minimizing bowel function impact.

Anterior Resection

Preferred for most cancers in the middle and lower rectum; involves removing affected rectal parts and reconnecting the colon to the remaining rectum.

Abdominoperineal Excision (APR)

(Option D ruled out)

Reserved for low-lying, extensive tumours unsuitable for sphincter-saving; involves removing rectum, anus, and surrounding tissues, creating a permanent colostomy.

Hartmann's Procedure

Involves removing the rectum and creating a temporary colostomy, suitable for elderly or frail patients.

Pelvic Exenteration: Radical surgery for advanced cases with cancer spread to adjacent organs; removes rectum, bladder, prostate (in men), and/or reproductive organs (in women) for clear margins.

Non-Surgical Treatment:

  • Wait and watch:
    • Considered for patients with complete clinical response to neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (about 20% of cases); involves close monitoring with potential surgery if recurrence occurs.
  • Endoluminal Stenting:
    • Used palliatively to relieve obstruction from inoperable tumours or to facilitate elective surgery; suitable for tumours in the upper rectum or rectosigmoid junction.
  • Palliative Colostomy:
    • Indicated in inoperable rectal cancer or cancers causing obstruction.

Adjuvant Therapy

  • Radiotherapy:
    • May be used pre- or post-surgery to destroy remaining cancer cells and reduce recurrence risk.
  • Chemotherapy:
    • Typically 5-fluorouracil(5-FU) based regimens are often combined with radiotherapy or given post-surgery to eliminate remaining cancer cells.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with bright red, painless rectal bleeding and a feeling of incomplete evacuation. Digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals a firm, irregular, palpable mass located 6 cm from the anal verge. Which statement about the clinical features of rectal carcinoma is most accurate?

choices.text: Rectal carcinoma typically presents without any changes in bowel habits.
Rectal carcinoma is most common in patients under 55 years of age.
The presence of a hard mass within 7-8 cm of the anal verge.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The presence of a firm mass within 7-8 cm of the anal verge.

Explanation:

  • The rectal neoplasm may be palpable within 7-8 cm of the anal verge, appearing as a raised, firm mass.

Clinical Features of Rectal Carcinoma:

  1. Commonly seen in >55 years of age (Option C ruled out)
  2. Early Symptoms:
    1. Bleeding per rectum: The most common early symptom, often bright red and painless, which can be mistaken for hemorrhoidal bleeding.
    2. Tenesmus: It is an important early symptom. It is the feeling of incomplete evacuation, often present with lower rectal tumours, leading to frequent attempts to pass stool or gas. (Option A ruled out)
    3. Diarrhoea: Early morning diarrhoea may occur. (Option B ruled out)
  3. Late Symptoms:
    1. Constipation can develop with rectosigmoid junction tumours. (Option B ruled out)
    2. Colicky pain may indicate obstruction and advanced cancers may cause severe pain due to invasion of nearby structures.
    3. Weight loss indicates metastatic disease.
  4. Abdominal Examination Findings:
    1. Early cases may be normal while obstructing tumours can show signs of subacute bowel obstruction.
    2. Palpable liver enlargement may indicate liver metastases, and cachexia can be present.
    3. Ascites may be found in cases of peritoneal spread.
  5. Rectal Examination Findings:
    1. The tumour is palpable within 7-8 cm of the anal verge, appearing as a raised, hard mass. If ulcerated, it may present as a depression with everted edges. (Option D)
    2. Mobility and distance from the anal sphincter complex are important for assessing resectability and surgical planning.

questions.text: A 24 y/o male presents with intermittent pain and discharge at the natal cleft after experiencing recurrent abscesses in the area. He reports that the symptoms worsen after prolonged sitting and has a history of coarse hair. Upon examination, a midline opening is noted in the natal cleft. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?

choices.text: Complete surgical excision of the sinus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Drainage through a midline incision

Explanation:

  • Drainage through a midline incision is the most appropriate initial management for an acute pilonidal abscess.
  • It involves creating a small incision to drain the abscess and clean the cavity.
  • Pilonidal sinuses are found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair.

 

Treatment Options:

Treatment Type

Description

Conservative Treatment
  • For mild cases: cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance.
  • Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser in less complex cases.

Acute Abscess Treatment
  • Drainage through a small longitudinal incision over the abscess (Option C).
  • Thorough cleaning of the abscess cavity to remove granulation tissue and hair.

Surgical Treatment

Procedures include:

  • Laying open sinus tracks (with/without marsupialisation)
  • Complete excision (with/without primary closure)
  • Off-midline closure techniques (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedures).
  • Bascom Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus cavity, excise midline pits, and leave lateral wounds open to heal secondarily.
  • Flap Procedures: Used if initial treatments fail or if the sinus recurs.

Pilonidal sinus excision and repair by rhomboid flap:

questions.text: A 32 y/o woman presents with severe pain during bowel movements and bright red blood on toilet paper for 2 weeks. She describes the pain as excruciating and sharp, akin to "passing glass.” Based on this clinical scenario, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: It mainly presents with anal itching & discharge
The hallmark symptom is severe pain during defecation that usually subsides after bowel movements.
This condition is characterized by a thickened anal papilla and a skin tag.
The majority of cases occur in the anterior midline in women due to childbirth.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The hallmark symptom is severe pain during defecation that usually subsides after bowel movements.

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis of the given scenario is acute anal fissure.
  • Severe pain during defecation that usually subsides afterwards is a key feature of this condition

Anal Fissure

  • Most anal fissures occur in the posterior midline due to concentrated pressure during bowel movements. (Option D ruled out)
  • Anterior anal fissures are more common in women, often linked to childbirth trauma.
  • They may be acute or chronic as described below

Feature

Acute Anal Fissures

Chronic Anal Fissures

Cause

Trauma to the anal canal lining. (Passage of hard stools, prolonged diarrhoea, childbirth).

Increased anal sphincter tone converts acute to chronic fissure,

  • Elevated muscle tension reduces blood flow to the anal canal.
  • Impaired healing leads to a cycle of repeated injury.

Pain

Excruciating, sharp pain during defecation (described as "passing glass").

May be less intense than acute but can still be painful.

Duration of Pain

The pain subsides after defecation but returns with the next bowel movement. (Option B)

Persistent pain may occur, with periods of discomfort.

Bleeding

Bright red blood on toilet paper after wiping.

May also experience blood but less prominently reported.

Physical Exam

Difficult without anaesthesia due to intense pain.

An exam may be possible, with signs of irritation from the skin tag.

Additional Symptoms

Notable pain prevents physical examination; anal spasms may be present.

Presents with anal itching, discharge, or intersphincteric fistula. (Option A ruled out)

Identifying Features

Fresh, superficial tears in the anal canal.

Thickened anal papilla and skin tag present; fissure between these structures. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 35 y/o woman presents with severe pain during bowel movements and bright red blood on toilet tissue. Upon examination, the physician suspects an anal fissure. Which of the following characteristics is most likely associated with a chronic anal fissure?

choices.text: Presence of bright red blood only after bowel movements.
Severe sharp pain during bowel movements that subside afterwards.
Thickened anal papilla and skin tag are present at the fissure site.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thickened anal papilla and skin tag present at the fissure site

Explanation:

  • The presence of a thickened anal papilla and an external skin tag is a characteristic of chronic fissures.

Anal Fissures: Ulcer in the longitudinal axis of the anal canal

 

 

Characteristic

Acute Anal Fissures

Chronic Anal Fissures

Description

Fresh, superficial tears in the anal canal lining.

Develop when acute fissures fail to heal due to ongoing trauma and increased anal sphincter tone.

Symptoms
  • Severe, sharp pain during bowel movements (subsides afterwards)(Option B ruled out)
  • Bright red blood on toilet tissue after wiping(Option A ruled out).
  • Physical examination often requires general anaesthesia due to pain.
  • Presence of a thickened anal papilla and an external skin tag(Option C).
  • May cause anal itching due to skin tag irritation.
  • Discharge from the fissure or a co-existing intersphincteric fistula.
  • Often less painful than acute fissures due to associated inflammation.

questions.text: During a detailed anatomical study, a researcher examines the fascia layers associated with the rectum. Which of the following structures separates the rectum from the prostate in males?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Denonvilliers' fascia
 

Explanation:

  • Denonvilliers' fascia is the membranous layer located anterior to the rectum, acting as a barrier between the rectum and the prostate, seminal vesicles, and bladder in males.

Presacral fascia (Option A):

  • Situated posterior to the rectum, covering the anterior surface of the sacrum and coccyx.

Fascia propria (Option B):

  • Thin layer of fascia around the mesorectum, which surrounds the rectum.

Waldeyer's fascia (Option D (also known as recto sacral fascia):

  • Condensation of endopelvic fascia connecting the presacral fascia to the fascia propria at the S4 level. It separates the rectum from the sacrum.

questions.text: A 32 y/o male presents with intermittent discharge of pus from an external opening near the anus, accompanied by discomfort and occasional blood in the discharge. He has a history of anorectal abscess treated six months ago and reports pain during bowel movements. Which of the following is the investigation of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MRI


Explanation:

  • MRI (MR fistulogram) is the investigation of choice as it provides detailed images of the fistula tunnel, the sphincter muscle, and other pelvic floor structures.
  • It can identify secondary extensions and associated complications that may influence surgical management.

Investigations for Fistula-in-Ano

 

MRI (Option D)

Maps the fistula tunnel and provides detailed images of the sphincter muscle and pelvic floor structures. (Investigation of choice)

Endoscopic Ultrasound (Option B ruled out)

It uses high-frequency sound waves to identify the fistula, sphincter muscles, and surrounding tissues.

Fistulography (Option A ruled out)

An X-ray procedure using injected contrast to visualize the anal fistula tunnel.

Examination Under Anesthesia

Allows for thorough evaluation of the fistula tunnel and identification of potential complications.

Fistula Probe

A specialized instrument is inserted through the fistula to identify the fistula tunnel.

Anoscopy (Option C ruled out)

A small endoscope is used to visualize the anal canal for assessment of fistulas during anoscopy

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents to the clinic with a persistent anal discharge and discomfort. He has a history of recurrent perianal abscesses over the past year. O/E an external opening is noted near the anal margin. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the anal fistula in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cryptoglandular infection

 

Explanation:

  • Cryptoglandular infection is the most common cause of anal fistulas, particularly following an anorectal abscess, as mentioned in the above scenario.

 

Fistula-in-Ano

  • A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.
 

Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis. (Option D)
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease(Option A ruled out)
    • Tuberculosis (Option B ruled out)
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis (Option C ruled out)
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with severe anal pain and a tender, indurated lump at the anal margin. He reports a two-day history of progressively localized pain but has no systemic symptoms such as fever or malaise. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Surgical drainage under anaesthesia

 

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation with a tender, palpable mass at the anal verge and localized pain suggests an abscess that requires prompt surgical drainage, which is the definitive treatment to prevent complications.

Anorectal Abscess: 

  • A localized collection of pus in the perianal or perirectal region, often resulting from a cryptoglandular infection.

 

Treatment:

  • Surgical Drainage: Primary treatment, often performed under anaesthesia. (Option B)
    • Perianal and Ischiorectal Abscesses: Drained via perineal skin using a cruciate incision, avoiding excessive excision of healthy tissue.
    • Supralevator Sepsis: Management depends on the origin; may require intrarectal drainage or treatment of underlying pelvic disease.
  • Antibiotics: Indicated in cases with extensive cellulitis, diabetes, or immunosuppression.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male reports deep, intense pain "inside" the anal area that worsens with coughing or sneezing. The examination shows minimal external swelling, but the significant discomfort prevents a complete digital rectal exam. Given this clinical picture, which type of anorectal abscess is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intersphincteric Abscess
 

Explanation:

  • The scenario describes intense, deep anal pain with minimal external signs and difficulty in performing a digital rectal exam, which is characteristic of an intersphincteric abscess.
  • This type of abscess presents with few external signs but causes severe pain which is exacerbated by actions like coughing or sneezing.
  • Once identified, the abscess can be drained through a limited, typically posterior, internal sphincterotomy, usually performed under anaesthesia.

Classification of Anorectal Abscess

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with difficulty urinating and lower abdominal discomfort. The doctor advises a digital rectal examination (DRE) to assess for potential prostate enlargement or other rectal abnormalities. Which of the following is not an external inspection finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rectal polyps

Explanation:

  • Rectal polyps are identified through internal inspection, not external.


Digital rectal examination

  • Diagnostic process in cases including, but not limited to, gastrointestinal bleeding, inflammatory bowel disease, haemorrhoids, constipation, trauma, and neurological disorders

 

Rectal exam findings on external and internal inspection:

External Inspection

Internal Inspection
  • Anal fissures (Option A)
  • Anal fistula
  • Genital warts
  • External haemorrhoids (Option D)
  • Pilonidal sinus (Option C)
  • Skin disease (seborrhoeic eczema, skin cancer, natal cleft dermatitis)
  • Skin tags
  • Skin discoloration with Crohn's disease
  • Rectal prolapse
  • Internal haemorrhoids
  • Rectal carcinoma
  • Rectal polyps
  • Tenderness with prostatitis or acute appendicitis
  • Malignant or inflammatory conditions of the peritoneum with anterior palpation

questions.text: A 72-year-old multiparous woman presents with a painless mass protruding from her anus along with occasional bleeding and fecal incontinence. O/E the mass is circumferential, red in colour, and reducible. Which of the following is the most likely type of rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Complete prolapse

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario describes a complete prolapse.
  • Complete prolapse involves the descent of all layers of the rectum, leading to a full-thickness, circumferential protrusion that is often reducible and associated with symptoms such as bleeding and faecal incontinence.

 

Rectal Prolapse:

  • It is the circumferential descent of the rectum through the anal canal

 

Types of Rectal Prolapse:

Partial

Complete
  • Mucosal
  • There is no descent of the muscular layer.
  • It is the most common type of rectal prolapse.
  • History of mass per anum.
  • It is pink in colour and circumferential.
  • Complete-full thickness.
  • The descent contains all layers of the rectum (i.e. including the muscular layer).
  • Complete descent of rectum as mass per anum circumferentially which is red in colour.
  • Mass is usually reducible and painless.
  • It may be associated with uterine prolapse (uterine procidentia) in females.
  • Fecal incontinence (75%) is very common.
  • Bleeding can occur because of the congestion.
  • Sepsis, discharge, fever, and anaemia are other features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent bleeding from haemorrhoids despite dietary changes and non-operative treatments. Examination reveals third-degree internal haemorrhoids. Which of the following is not an indication of hemorrhoidectomy?

choices.text: 'Mixed' haemorrhoids with a well-defined external component

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Second-degree hemorrhoids

 

Explanation:

  • Second-degree haemorrhoids are usually managed by non-operative methods and are indicated for hemorrhoidectomy only if not cured by non-operative treatments.

 

Haemorrhoidectomy

  • A surgical procedure based on decreasing blood flow to the hemorrhoidal plexuses and excising redundant anoderm and mucosa.

 

Indications for Haemorrhoidectomy

  • Third- and fourth-degree haemorrhoids (Option A and D ruled out)
  • Second-degree haemorrhoids that have not been cured by non-operative treatments
  • ‘Mixed’ haemorrhoids when the external component is well-defined (Option C ruled out)
  • Bleeding causes anaemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with bright red bleeding during defecation and a prolapsed haemorrhoid that cannot be reduced manually. What is the most suitable management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hemorrhoidectomy

 

Explanation:

  • Prolapsed haemorrhoids that cannot be reduced manually are classified as 4th-degree haemorrhoids.
  • Operative hemorrhoidectomy is the standard treatment for fourth-degree addressing both the prolapse and associated symptoms.
  • It is the elective resection of symptomatic haemorrhoids by decreasing blood flow and excising redundant tissue.
    • Used in 3rd and 4th-degree haemorrhoids.

Treatment of Hemorrhoids

Medical Therapy

  • Dietary and Lifestyle Changes: Increased dietary fibre, stool softeners, fluid intake, and avoiding straining can improve first- and second-degree haemorrhoids. (Option A ruled out)

Procedures

Rubber Band Ligation

Effective for persistent bleeding in first, second, and selected third-degree haemorrhoids by strangulating tissue to prevent further bleeding or prolapse. (Option B ruled out)

Infrared Photocoagulation:

Suitable for small first and second-degree haemorrhoids, coagulating the underlying plexus.

Sclerotherapy

Involves injecting sclerosing agents into first, second, and some third-degree haemorrhoids to cause fibrosis. (Option C ruled out)

Excision of Thrombosed External Hemorrhoids

Elliptical excision under local anaesthesia for acutely thrombosed external haemorrhoids causing intense pain.

 

Surgical Procedures

 

Operative Hemorrhoidectomy

Elective resection of symptomatic haemorrhoids by decreasing blood flow and excising redundant tissue.Used in 3rd and 4th-degree haemorrhoids (Option D)

Doppler-Guided Hemorrhoidal Artery Ligation

Uses a Doppler probe to identify and ligate arteries feeding the hemorrhoidal plexus, promising for symptomatic hemorrhoids but long-term effectiveness is still being evaluated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man reports experiencing bright red bleeding during bowel movements and a mass that protrudes from his anus, which he can manually reduce but does not reduce spontaneously. On examination, no thrombosed haemorrhoids are observed. Which degree of internal haemorrhoids is this patient most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Third degree

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario describes a patient with internal haemorrhoids that prolapse through the anal canal and require manual reduction and do not reduce spontaneously.
  • This is characteristic of third-degree haemorrhoids.

 

Internal Haemorrhoids are classified into

  • First-degree haemorrhoids: 
    • Bulge into the anal canal and may prolapse beyond the dentate line on straining. (Option A ruled out)
  • Second-degree haemorrhoids: 
    • Prolapse through the anus but reduce spontaneously. (Option B ruled out)
  • Third-degree haemorrhoids: 
    • Prolapse through the anal canal and require manual reduction. (Option C)
  • Fourth-degree haemorrhoids:
    • ​​​​​​​Prolapse but cannot be reduced and are at risk for strangulation. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 55 y/o woman presents with complaints of rectal bleeding and discomfort during bowel movements. She mentions experiencing chronic constipation and frequent straining. Which pathophysiological mechanism is most likely contributing to her haemorrhoids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Increased intra-abdominal pressure

 

Explanation:

  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure, often due to chronic straining during bowel movements, is a significant factor in the development of haemorrhoids.
  • This increased pressure causes the veins in the rectal area to swell and become engorged, leading to haemorrhoids.
  • The patient's history of chronic constipation and frequent straining strongly suggests that increased intra-abdominal pressure is the primary pathophysiological mechanism in this case.

questions.text: A 58 y/o male presents with rectal cancer located just distal to the dentate line. During his evaluation for metastatic spread, which lymph nodes are most likely to be involved given the location of his cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Inguinal lymph nodes

 

Explanation:

  • Inguinal lymph nodes are involved in the drainage of areas distal to the dentate line, including the anus.
  • Due to the direct lymphatic drainage pattern, the inguinal lymph nodes are most likely involved in rectal cancers located just distal to the dentate line.

 

Internal iliac lymph nodes (Option A):

  • These nodes are involved in the drainage of the lower rectum and pelvic organs.


Inferior mesenteric lymph nodes (Option B):

  • These nodes drain the upper two-thirds of the rectum and are important for mid to upper rectal cancers.

 

Para-aortic lymph nodes (Option C):

  • These nodes receive lymphatic drainage from the upper rectum via the inferior mesenteric lymph nodes.
